entry.title: Jebena Cafe, Seattle
entry.content:
just when you think you've tasted everything

This is ful medames, served for breakfast at Jebena Cafe, an Ethiopian restaurant Andou and I discovered some time ago. It contains fava beans, olive oil, tomatoes, green onions, feta, boiled egg, and other things I can't remember. You eat it with crisp, freshly-made baguette bread, and it's one of the most startlingly wonderful and fresh tastes I've ever discovered.

entry.title: Prasad, Portland, Or
entry.content:
Waiting for Powell's to open one morning in December, Andou and I found Prasad, a yoga-studio-slash-raw-food-restaurant serving breakfast.  I don't remember the exact names of the food we ordered, but it was essentially

  • apple ginger smoothie thing
  • bread that was brown
  • almond butter
  • vegan butter (potentially made with various milks)
  • noodle bowl dish (actually comprised of curl-cut squash and carrot ribbons, not noodles)

We ate at a table decorated with a succulent in a wineglass.  It was all delicious and remarkably filling.

I've worked at only two restaurants in my lifetime (a teriyaki/pho place and the campus cafe), but occasionally I miss the easy camaraderie of it, how easy it is to interact with people when you're delegated to understood roles: diner, server.

And it would of course be a plus to learn how to make food like this on my own.  (Somehow I imagine it would be more rewarding than coming away from being a barista with a grimacing suspicion of anyone making your coffee.)

entry.title: Ohana's
entry.content:
Spam musubi!

Ohana in Belltown is "a Japanese-Polynesian grill and bamboo sushi lounge" and has been the place for a lot of my friends' 21sts, usually to good effect (though I guess the waitress during my 21st was a little rude? I was too busy having fun to notice...mostly). I've never been there outside of happy hour.

My favorite two types of sushi at the fore <3
And Andrea's unagi in the background, which I can't eat because my family curse

I don't usually have much of a discerning taste when it comes to sushi (since I dislike the kinds with non-salmon fish, which rules out the majority of sushi), but the California rolls here are somehow way more delicious than anywhere else I've tried them.  The spam musubi are also super huge, and the gyoza is good too.

omgggg you know you want this

I've tasted some sort of really tasty drink that they serve in a white plastic bucket -- something very tropical and sweet and pineapple-y -- but I don't know what it's called, and every time I try to order it the waiters never have any idea what I'm talking about, so it's probably some mysterious special.  The Mala Shake (which is actually on the menu) suffices after failed attempts.

This will be the last time you ever see it
